article.title: Theory of hyperbolic stratified nanostructures for surface enhanced Raman scattering

multiple_choice_question.text: The dispersion relation for uniaxial hyperbolic materials (HMs), as described in Equation (1), defines a relationship between which of the following quantities?
choices: Wavevector (k), angular frequency (ω), and speed of light (c)
Wavevector (k), angular frequency (ω), and dielectric tensor elements (ε)
Angular frequency (ω), speed of light (c), and dielectric tensor elements (ε)
Wavevector (k), speed of light (c), and permeability (μ)

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main reason for the lower radiative efficiency and single-photon β factors observed in HM-based nanostructures compared to pure metal counterparts?
choices: Lower LDOS enhancement
Increased scattering losses
Increased absorption and quenching
Reduced Purcell factor

multiple_choice_question.text: What is a key advantage of the quantum optics theory used to describe SERS in this article?
choices: It relies solely on classical electromagnetism for a simpler approach.
It exclusively utilizes Density Functional Theory for precise molecular descriptions.
It accurately predicts SERS enhancement using only the excitation field enhancement.
It employs a versatile technique applicable to various plasmonic nanostructures and provides an intuitive understanding of SERS.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of using the full photon Green function (G(r, r\';ω)) in the quantum optomechanical formalism of SERS?
choices: It simplifies the calculation by neglecting quenching effects.
It focuses solely on the radiative part of the LDOS.
It accurately captures the complete frequency response of the plasmonic enhancement, including quenching effects.
It eliminates the need for considering different nanostructures in the theoretical framework.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the prefactor A(WL, Eo) in Equation (7) for describing the Raman scattering spectrum?
choices: It represents the plasmonic enhancement of the intrinsic Raman scattering rate of a molecule.
It quantifies the propagation effects of the scattered field from the molecule to the detector.
It accounts for the plasmonic enhancement of the induced Raman dipole.
It describes the emitted spectral function for the Raman scattered photons.
